utterances: That's interesting.
You say when you were a little boy...
Yeah.
It was about--I think I must have been about 10.
Who took you there?
Your parents took you?
No, it was my uncle.
Your uncle took you.
Yeah.
And you were very small.
Yeah.
And that was a memory.
You remember, though, don't you?
Yeah.
I remembered Woody at that time, yeah.
What was it stuck in your mind?
That--it stuck in my mind that he was Woody and everybody else I could see around me was just everybody else.
Aha.
But he was Woody, and...
You mean, there was no one else but one...
Yeah.
...and that was he.
And I think, if I may venture an opinion, there's no one else but one, too, here in you, Bob.
That, of course, was Bob Dylan talking about Woody Guthrie and seeing Woody Guthrie as a little boy.
What was Bob Dylan like?
Yeah.
Well, of course, I knew Woody very well, much better than I knew Dylan.
The time I interviewed Bob was the one time, one of his earliest, '63; he was 22 years old.
Twenty-two.
I remember the first words I said, `Where have you been, Cotton-Eye Joe?
That's the ...(unintelligible) reading.
But he spoke of a certain song.
First of all, the implements of Woody on him.
And then he sang the song, ""Hard Rain's A-Gonna Fall."" And he said, `Every line of that song could be the subject of a different song.'
But there was one line that knocked my wife out for a loop and the line was, `The executioner's face is always well hidden.
And that line--you think naturally the guillotine, the guy who wields the ax has a mask over his face, the guy who hangs people has a mask over his face.
And today, thanks to technology, and bombings from afar, the executioner's face may be celebrated, maybe a high official.
At the same time, it may not be well-hidden, it is there.
Mm-hmm.
And so phrase and the way he would use that phrase is what distinguished him.
But his tribute to Woody is one I remember best.
See, so I have to say Bob Dylan did not come out of the womb whole; he was influenced by others.
Yeah.
And Woody, I think, I call the balladeer of the Great Depression.

Well, the documentary that this caller just referred to, I saw some of it, too, that just recently aired on some public stations done by Martin Scorsese, really showed that influence that Woody Guthrie had on Bob Dylan.
It was very interesting.
And I hadn't realized the...
Yeah.
...the degree to which he had been influenced by him until then.
I--if I may, on that subject...
Yes.
Just one second.
OK.
Let me remind our audience that you're listening to...
Oh, go ahead.
I'm sorry.
I just want to tell them that you're listening to TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
Go ahead.
Woody was his own kind of poet.
Like, following Caruso, I'd have

Louis Armstrong, and I'd have Woody doing, say, ""Tom Joad."" Now ""Tom Joad"" is one of his Dust Bowl ballads; Tom, we know, the hero of ""Grapes of Wrath."" In six minutes--it's two sides of a 10-inch 78 RPM--in those six minutes, he captures the whole novel, the key of all the revelatory moments of John Steinbeck's 600-or-so-page book.
It's astonishing.
At the end, he says goodbye to his mother that he loved--Remember that great line?
He says, `Mamma, where am I going to find you?
We know he's going to be in Oregon.
As he goes off, she says, `Wherever the kid's hungry for bread, crying for bread, I'll be there.
Wherever men eat the crops they raise, live alone as they build, I'll be there.
So you'll know I am, Mother,' etc. But...
All right.
Let's see if we can get one more call in before we have to let you go.
We're going to go to Art in Phoenix, Arizona.
Hi, Art.
Unidentified Man #2: They are coming in first, buying the meat.
Then they disappear and they leave us with the crowd.
Good afternoon.
My grandfather was Caruso's personal physician in New York.
And in 1917, Caruso drew a caricature in black and white, a sketch that I still have here in my home; Caruso drew it of my grandfather.

I'm wondering, first of all, did you know that Caruso had that talent?--because it's a wonderful sketch--and did you find that other people whose principal talent was known to folks had other hidden talents that they were equally good at?
I'm sure they were, but you pointed out something very good.
He was a wonderful cartoonist, a caricaturist.
He had that--there are several others that I can't think of at the moment I'm sure who had similar qualities of cartooning and drawing.
But Caruso's one of the best cases in point, and so there you are.
Here's someone very close.
You know, he died prematurely.
He was doing Samson, ""Samson and Delilah."" The funny thing is he pulled the pillars down, the pillars fell.
But by that time, I think he had a cancer that was incurable.
But he'd start naming these people, and they are giants, each in his/her own way.
Before I check out--I should say, check out in many ways--Lynn.
Before that, I said the gospel songs followed the Civil War, the gospel songs up North.
Now the spirituals were slavery songs.
They were code songs.
They were right out of Scripture, Old and New Testament.
`Didn't my Lord deliver Daniel, and why not every man?
Or `Swing low, sweet chariot, comin' for to carry me home.
Well, that sweet chariot could be the underground railway.
Yeah.
Yeah.
It's...
Let me just thank Art for calling in.
Hope you got your question answered.
Thanks so much for the call, Art.
I did, thank you.
Just, you know, when you look back at these interviews, is there--you said there's not one, but are there mom--is there a moment you remember or that you really cherish from some of these interviews?
Is there one you can think of?
Well, there are so many.
You know, hearing the guys Gillespie and Parker playing for the first time, inventing a new form called exploring the instrument ...(unintelligible) to bop.
But I see--to me, a moment is a singer named Claudia Muzio.
And people think of Callas as the great Fioretta in ""Traviata,"" and she was--but not better than Muzio, who sang at the Opera Company in Chicago a couple of times.
Muzio, in the opera, is dying.

The courtesan is reading a letter of apology from the rich guy whose son was in love with her, and she was in love with--she was a courtesan, and he says the son has to leave her 'cause she'll ruin the family's name.

And she reads the letter of apology from the old man, and then she starts singing the song, ""Addio, del passato,"" ""Farewell, Then, Forever."" As she reads that letter in Italian, you think Eleanora Duse, the greatest of all actresses, was doing it.
That to me is one of the high moments ever for me.
